trans-unit.source: lexical variables created with my(), our() or state().

lexical variables created with my(). Typically it would be the first declaration in a file included by the do, require, or use operators. You can switch into a package in more than one place; it merely influences which symbol table is used by the compiler for the rest of that block. You can refer to variables and filehandles in other packages by prefixing the identifier with the package name and a double colon: $Package::Variable . If the package name is null, the main package is assumed. That is, $::sail is equivalent to $main::sail .
trans-unit.target: variables léxicas creadas con my (). Normalmente, sería la primera declaración en un archivo incluido por los operadores do , require o use . Puede cambiar a un paquete en más de un lugar; simplemente influye en qué tabla de símbolos utiliza el compilador para el resto de ese bloque. Puede hacer referencia a variables y identificadores de archivos en otros paquetes colocando el prefijo del identificador con el nombre del paquete y dos puntos dobles: $Package::Variable . Si el nombre del paquete es nulo, se asume el paquete main . Es decir, $::sail es equivalente a $main::sail .

trans-unit.source: lexically-scoped variables, which are created with my, state, or our. Typically it would be the first declaration in a file included by require or use. You can switch into a package in more than one place, since this only determines which default symbol table the compiler uses for the rest of that block. You can refer to identifiers in other packages than the current one by prefixing the identifier with the package name and a double colon, as in $SomePack::var or ThatPack::INPUT_HANDLE. If package name is omitted, the main package as assumed. That is, $::sail is equivalent to $main::sail (as well as to $main'sail, still seen in ancient code, mostly from Perl 4).

lexically-scoped variables, which are created with my, state, or our. Typically it would be the first declaration in a file included by require or use. You can switch into a package in more than one place, since this only determines which default symbol table the compiler uses for the rest of that block. You can refer to identifiers in other packages than the current one by prefixing the identifier with the package name and a double colon, as in $SomePack::var or ThatPack::INPUT_HANDLE . If package name is omitted, the main package as assumed. That is, $::sail is equivalent to $main::sail (as well as to $main'sail , still seen in ancient code, mostly from Perl 4).
trans-unit.target: variables de ámbito léxico, que se crean con my , state o our . Normalmente, sería la primera declaración en un archivo incluido por require o use . Puede cambiar a un paquete en más de un lugar, ya que esto solo determina qué tabla de símbolos predeterminada usa el compilador para el resto de ese bloque. Puede hacer referencia a identificadores en otros paquetes además del actual colocando el prefijo del identificador con el nombre del paquete y dos puntos dobles, como en $SomePack::var o ThatPack::INPUT_HANDLE . Si se omite el nombre del paquete, se asume el paquete main . Es decir, $::sail es equivalente a $main::sail (así como a $main'sail , todavía visto en código antiguo, principalmente de Perl 4).

trans-unit.source: may be an unknown concept to some readers. The ISO 8601 standard defines that weeks begin on a Monday and week 1 of the year is the week that includes both January 4th and the first Thursday of the year. In other words, if the first Monday of January is the 2nd, 3rd, or 4th, the preceding days of the January are part of the last week of the preceding year. Week numbers range from 1 to 53.
trans-unit.target: puede ser un concepto desconocido para algunos lectores.La norma ISO 8601 define que las semanas comienzan un lunes y la semana 1 del año es la semana que incluye tanto el 4 de enero como el primer jueves del año.En otras palabras,si el primer lunes de enero es el 2,3 o 4,los días precedentes de enero forman parte de la última semana del año anterior.Los números de la semana van del 1 al 53.

trans-unit.source: means some operators are evaluated before others. For example, in 2 + 4 * 5 , the multiplication has higher precedence so 4 * 5 is evaluated first yielding 2 + 20 == 22 and not 6 * 5 == 30 .
trans-unit.target: significa que algunos operadores se evalúan antes que otros. Por ejemplo, en 2 + 4 * 5 , la multiplicación tiene mayor prioridad, por lo que 4 * 5 se evalúa primero, lo que da como resultado 2 + 20 == 22 y no 6 * 5 == 30 .

trans-unit.source: means some operators group more tightly than others. For example, in 2 + 4 * 5, the multiplication has higher precedence, so 4 * 5 is grouped together as the right-hand operand of the addition, rather than 2 + 4 being grouped together as the left-hand operand of the multiplication. It is as if the expression were written 2 + (4 * 5), not (2 + 4) * 5. So the expression yields 2 + 20 == 22, rather than 6 * 5 == 30.

means that all the elements of the map array are either rational numbers or the string "NaN" , meaning "Not a Number". A rational number is either an integer, or two integers separated by a solidus ("/" ). The second integer represents the denominator of the division implied by the solidus, and is actually always positive, so it is guaranteed not to be 0 and to not be signed. When the element is a plain integer (without the solidus), it may need to be adjusted to get the correct value by adding the offset, just as other "a" properties. No adjustment is needed for fractions, as the range is guaranteed to have just a single element, and so the offset is always 0.
trans-unit.target: significa que todos los elementos de la matriz de mapas son números racionales o la cadena "NaN" , que significa "No es un número". Un número racional es un número entero o dos enteros separados por un sólido ( "/" ). El segundo número entero representa el denominador de la división implícita en el solidus, y en realidad siempre es positivo, por lo que se garantiza que no sea 0 y que no tenga signo. Cuando el elemento es un entero simple (sin el solidus), es posible que deba ajustarse para obtener el valor correcto agregando el desplazamiento, al igual que otras propiedades "a" . No se necesita ningún ajuste para las fracciones, ya que se garantiza que el rango tiene un solo elemento, por lo que el desplazamiento es siempre 0.

trans-unit.source: means that all the elements of the map array are either rational numbers or the string "NaN", meaning "Not a Number". A rational number is either an integer, or two integers separated by a solidus ("/"). The second integer represents the denominator of the division implied by the solidus, and is actually always positive, so it is guaranteed not to be 0 and to not be signed. When the element is a plain integer (without the solidus), it may need to be adjusted to get the correct value by adding the offset, just as other "a" properties. No adjustment is needed for fractions, as the range is guaranteed to have just a single element, and so the offset is always 0.

trans-unit.source: means to use Unicode rules when pattern matching. On ASCII platforms, this means that the code points between 128 and 255 take on their Latin-1 (ISO-8859-1) meanings (which are the same as Unicode's). (Otherwise Perl considers their meanings to be undefined.) Thus, under this modifier, the ASCII platform effectively becomes a Unicode platform; and hence, for example, \w will match any of the more than 100_000 word characters in Unicode.
trans-unit.target: significa utilizar reglas Unicode al hacer coincidir patrones. En las plataformas ASCII, esto significa que los puntos de código entre 128 y 255 adquieren sus significados Latin-1 (ISO-8859-1) (que son los mismos que los de Unicode). (De lo contrario, Perl considera que sus significados no están definidos). Por lo tanto, bajo este modificador, la plataforma ASCII se convierte efectivamente en una plataforma Unicode; y por lo tanto, por ejemplo, \w coincidirá con cualquiera de los más de 100_000 caracteres de palabras en Unicode.

trans-unit.source: means to use the current locale's rules (see perllocale) when pattern matching. For example, \w will match the "word" characters of that locale, and "/i" case-insensitive matching will match according to the locale's case folding rules. The locale used will be the one in effect at the time of execution of the pattern match. This may not be the same as the compilation-time locale, and can differ from one match to another if there is an intervening call of the setlocale() function.
trans-unit.target: significa usar las reglas de la configuración regional actual (ver perllocale ) cuando se emparejan patrones. Por ejemplo, \w coincidirá con los caracteres de "palabra" de esa configuración regional, y la coincidencia "/i" que no distinga entre mayúsculas y minúsculas coincidirá de acuerdo con las reglas de plegado de mayúsculas y minúsculas de la configuración regional. La configuración regional utilizada será la que esté en vigor en el momento de la ejecución de la coincidencia de patrones. Este puede no ser el mismo que el entorno local en tiempo de compilación y puede diferir de una coincidencia a otra si hay una llamada intermedia de la función setlocale () .

At each character position, Perl will first try to match the first alternative, dog. If dog doesn't match, Perl will then try the next alternative, cat. If cat doesn't match either, then the match fails and Perl moves to the next position in the string. Some examples:

trans-unit.source: modules on your nearby CPAN mirror) and the name "crypt" is a bit of a misnomer. Instead it is primarily used to check if two pieces of text are the same without having to transmit or store the text itself. An example is checking if a correct password is given. The digest of the password is stored, not the password itself. The user types in a password that is crypt'd with the same salt as the stored digest. If the two digests match, the password is correct.
